summary: mechanically ventilated SARS patients were sedated and received mechanical ventilation in the isolation intensive care unit (ICU) they were divided into two groups either with or without pneumothorax. the mortality rate was similar between the groups. peiris et al. identified a high incidence of pneumomediastinum (12%) in a general population of SARS patients. lew and Fowler also observed a high incidence of pneumothorax (20 to 34%) in mechanically ventilated SARS patients. patients with pre-existing pneumothorax or chest tube thoracostomy excluded. primary study outcome variable defined as radiographic evidence of new-onset pneumothorax at 30 days after ventilator use. patients were censored at the first pneumothorax event, at the time of death, liberation from mechanical ventilation or discharge from the SARS ICU. non-parametric tests were chosen because of the small sample size in the pneumothorax group. p value of less than 0.05 was considered to indicate
